story_headline: Biden: We‚Äôll stick with Ukraine for ‚Äòas long as it takes‚Äô
story_copy: President Joe Biden reaffirmed America‚Äôs commitment to help Ukraine combat Russia‚Äôs invasion. He pledged another $800 million in security assistance to Ukraine. While wrapping up the NATO summit in Madrid on Thursday, Biden said the new package includes more ammunition and artillery and advanced air defense systems.‚ÄúThe war could end tomorrow, by the way, if Russia stops its irrational behavior,‚Äù stated the President. ‚ÄúSo, you know, when the war will end, you know I hope it ends sooner than later, but for it to end they have to be in a position where‚Ä¶the the Ukrainians have all that they can reasonably expect. We can reasonably expect to get to them in order to provide for provide for their physical security and their defenses.‚ÄùThis came after Biden shared a phone call with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan while on his way to the summit in which he urged him to sign off on Finland and Sweden joining the NATO alliance.President Biden participated in the NATO Summit, taking place in Madrid, Spain, where he met with Allied Heads of State and Government. pic.twitter.com/GWEJpcUv47‚Äî The White House (@WhiteHouse) June 29, 2022Leaders strengthened defense along the eastern flank as Biden announced a boost of US military presence in Europe in response to Russian threats. This includes adding a permanent army headquarters in Poland, sending new warships to Spain fighter jet squadrons to Britain and deploying additional troops to Romania as well as increasing rotational deployments in the Baltic states.Biden assured the transatlantic alliance is stronger than ever before, but continued to blame Russia‚Äôs war on Ukraine for America‚Äôs rampant inflation.‚ÄúBut the bottom line is ultimately the reason why gas prices are up is because of Russia, Russia, Russia, Russia,‚Äù said the President. ‚ÄúThe reason why the food crisis exists is because of Russia. Russia not allowing grain to get out of Ukraine and so, that‚Äôs the that‚Äôs the way in which I think we should move. And I think it will have a positive impact on the price at the pump as well.‚Äù-Canceled drilling leases-Canceled pipelines -Limited domestic production-Imposed needless regulations-Discouraged energy investmentsGas prices aren't high because of the war in Ukraine. They're high because of Joe Biden!‚Äî Rep. Jim Jordan (@Jim_Jordan) June 29, 2022In the meantime, as Biden returns to the White House, he‚Äôs scheduled to head to Saudi Arabia next month. While sending Americans into further turmoil, Biden said he will not directly ask the Saudi government to increase oil production, which could bring down the global price of energy.
image_caption: President Joe Biden speaks during a news conference on the final day of the NATO summit in Madrid, Thursday, June 30, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)

story_headline: Blake Masters has a ‚Äòmaster‚Äô plan for Ariz.
story_copy: Blake Masters has a ‚Äòmaster‚Äô plan for Ariz.OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:47 AM PT ‚Äì Friday, July 1, 2022Blake Masters was a student at Stanford Law School in 2012 when his notes on Pay Pal co-founder Peter Thiel‚Äôs computer science startup class became an internet sensation. Masters transformed those class notes into a New York Times bestseller: ‚ÄúZero to One: Notes on Startups or How to Build the Future.‚ÄùBefore then, he was named one of Forbes Top 30 Under 30 in 2014. Masters helped top tier companies work through the tough questions and creating new value, instead of merely copying what‚Äôs worked in the past. He‚Äôs looking to make those talents and entrepreneurial insights work for the people of Arizona. Former President Donald Trump believes he can.COMPLETE AND TOTAL ENDORSEMENT pic.twitter.com/T02CPKYRRp‚Äî Blake Masters (@bgmasters) June 27, 2022Trump said Masters will protect America‚Äôs borders, stand for life and election integrity. The 45th President warned Arizonans that other Senate candidates like Mark Brnovich and Jim Lamon will only let them down.Masters has been critical of Democrat Sen. Mark Kelly, particularly for his support for the nomination of Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court. Masters said putting Jackson on the Supreme Court is unthinkable.‚ÄúBut this vote, this disastrous vote will be his legacy,‚Äù Masters stated. ‚ÄúTo put a pedophile apologist on the Supreme Court, it makes my blood boil‚Ä¶‚ÄùHis time in Silicon Valley has showed him that an unholy alliance between Big Government, Big Tech and Big Business threatens to permanently upend America. As a Christian, husband, father, businessman, gun owner and an early member of President Trump‚Äôs MAGA movement, Masters refuses to let that happen. Arizona‚Äôs GOP Senate primary is set to take place August 2.

story_headline: N.Y. to bar concealed carry in various locations, increase requirements
story_copy: N.Y. to bar concealed carry in various locations, increase requirementsOAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:02 AM PT ‚Äì Friday, July 1, 2022The Empire State is striking back against a recent Supreme Court ruling on the Second Amendment. Governor Kathy Hochul (D) unveiled a list of ‚Äúsensitive locations‚Äù where concealed carriers will not be permitted to bring their firearms. During a press conference Wednesday, the Democrat rattled off a number of locations where the Second Amendment does not apply.‚ÄúFederal, state, local government buildings, health and medical facilities, places where children gather, daycares, parks, zoos, playgrounds, public transportation, subways, buses, polling places, educational institutions,‚Äù Hochul noted. ‚ÄúAnd making sure that we have no open-carry policy as a default position for private businesses.‚ÄùHochul clarified that private businesses wishing to allow patrons to carry a concealed firearm in their establishments must put up signage expressly giving permission to do so. The move is a rebuttal to the Supreme Court ruling that struck down the New York‚Äôs strict ‚Äúproper cause‚Äù requirement for those seeking concealed carry permits. The Democrat also pledged to make CCW and gun ownership requirements stricter to prevent criminals from stealing weapons from law-abiding citizens.‚ÄúTwenty-five percent of gun crimes are committed with stolen guns. Where can they steal out of?‚Äù asked Hochul. ‚ÄúThey can steal the out of your vehicle, so we‚Äôre adding a vehicle requirement to our safe storage laws. So you have to have them locked up when you‚Äôre traveling and right now, if you have children in your home under the age of 16, you have to have safe storage.‚ÄùThose seeking a concealed carry permit will be required to complete 15-hours of experience at a firing range, while background checks will be conducted for the purchases of both guns and ammunition. Hochul said the new law will serve as a baseline gun policy for the Empire State, but localities are welcome to enforce stricter measures at their own discretion. The governor used her parting words to lambaste the Supreme Court for striking down New York‚Äôs original protocol.‚ÄúAnd I wanna say, if six Supreme Court justices wanna take us backwards, we have a legislature full of duly elected representatives who actually speak for the people of this state and wanna protect a law that‚Äôs been on the books for over 100 years,‚Äù she asserted.Hochul called an ‚Äúextraordinary session‚Äù Thursday to push the measure through the state legislature.The Assembly Chambe is pictured as the house stands at ease during a special legislative session as lawmakers consider new firearms regulations for concealed-carry permits at the state Capitol, Thursday, June 30, 2022, in Albany, N.Y. (AP Photo/Hans Pennink)
image_caption: The Assembly Chambe is pictured as the house stands at ease during a special legislative session as lawmakers consider new firearms regulations for concealed-carry permits at the state Capitol, Thursday, June 30, 2022, in Albany, N.Y. (AP Photo/Hans Pennink)

story_headline: Israeli foreign minister ascends to prime minister
story_copy: Israeli foreign minister ascends to prime ministerIsraeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, left, and Foreign Minister Yair Lapid react after a vote on a bill to dissolve the parliament at the Knesset, Israel‚Äôs parliament, in Jerusalem, Thursday, June 30, 2022. Israel‚Äôs parliament has voted to dissolve itself, sending the country to the polls for the fifth time in less than four years. (AP Photo/Ariel Schalit)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:15 AM PT ‚Äì Friday, July 1, 2022Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett has officially stepped down from his position. In a ceremony Thursday, he handed the position over to the country‚Äôs foreign minister ‚Äî Yair Lapid.Congratulations to @YairLapid, Israel‚Äôs new Prime Minister, and thank you to Alternate Prime Minister @NaftaliBennett for your friendship over the past year.  I look forward to seeing you both in July to celebrate the unbreakable U.S.-Israel partnership.‚Äî President Biden (@POTUS) June 30, 2022Lapid‚Äôs ascension comes after the Israeli Parliament voted to dissolve themselves and the announcement of Bennett‚Äôs retirement from politics. Additionally, as part of a coalition agreement, Lapid will continue to function as Israel‚Äôs foreign minister alongside his new position.‚ÄúThis very special role and this state, it does not belong to one person, it belongs to all the people of Israel,‚Äù Bennett stated. ‚ÄúAnd I am passing to you this holy baton and the responsibility for the State of Israel, and I wish you that you will protect it and God will protect you.‚ÄùOutgoing Prime Minister Naftali Bennett and incoming Prime Minister Yair Lapid held a handover ceremony at the Prime Minister's Office in JerusalemAn orderly and in-depth transition meeting was then held between outgoing PM Bennett and incoming PM Lapidhttps://t.co/EXunxEssgs pic.twitter.com/qozGIrvO9e‚Äî Prime Minister of Israel (@IsraeliPM) June 30, 2022Bennett delivered some remarks during the hand-off ceremony in Jerusalem. Meanwhile, Israel will form a new cabinet in their November elections.
image_caption: Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, left, and Foreign Minister Yair Lapid react after a vote on a bill to dissolve the parliament at the Knesset, Israel‚Äôs parliament, in Jerusalem, Thursday, June 30, 2022. Israel‚Äôs parliament has voted to dissolve itself, sending the country to the polls for the fifth time in less than four years. (AP Photo/Ariel Schalit)

story_headline: Fla. Gov. Ron DeSantis gaining popularity as front runner for Oval Office in 2024
story_copy: Fla. Gov. Ron DeSantis gaining popularity as front runner for Oval Office in 2024Gov. Ron DeSantis, left, shakes hand with President Trump, right, at the Florida Fairgrounds. (AP Photo)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:54 PM PT ‚Äì Thursday, June 30, 2022Florida Governor Ron DeSantis is becoming a household name among Republicans, garnering praise for his strong leadership and taking on the Biden White House.Earlier this week, podcast host and UFC commentator Joe Rogan seemed to throw his weight behind DeSantis for a run at the Oval Office in 2024. Rogan praised the Florida Republican for his leadership through the pandemic while asserting he would make a much better leader than the current president.Rogan also called the governor‚Äôs decisions in the face of controversy ‚Äúadmirable,‚Äù while pointing to the harsh criticism DeSantis received for his COVID-19 policies, which ultimately proved to be just as or more successful than the response by Democrat states.‚ÄúI think Ron DeSantis would work as a good president,‚Äù Rogan stated. ‚Äú‚Ä¶He was correct when it comes to protecting our vulnerable populations. He was correct in terms of distribution of monoclonal antibodies, and he was furious when the government tried to pull those, they were trying to pull very effective treatments. You know, he is not perfect, he‚Äôs a human being, but what he‚Äôs done is stand up for freedoms. ‚ÄúRogan joined Tesla CEO Elon Musk in potentially backing DeSantis for president should he choose to run for the White House. Musk first expressed his support for the governor in a Twitter thread this month, saying he was ‚Äùleaning towards‚Äô backing him in 2024.While DeSantis has gained plaudits for his performance in office, former President Donald Trump has said he‚Äôs partially responsible for DeSantis winning the governor‚Äôs race in 2018. Trump has maintained the governor couldn‚Äôt have won the seat without his endorsement.DeSantis has largely brushed off questions about a future presidential bid while calling reporters questions ‚Äúfutile‚Äù and downplaying his political ambitions. Though he‚Äôs currently intent on earning a second term in the Sunshine State, recent polling indicates he and Trump would be among voters top choices in New Hampshire, which is¬† one of the first states being contested in the 2024 presidential primary.Meanwhile, Trump has not ruling out DeSantis could be his running mate in 2024. in a recent interview, the 45th President said neither ‚Äòyes‚Äô or ‚Äòno‚Äô when answering a question about his running mate. Trump explained that he has a ‚Äúgood relationship‚Äù with the Florida governor. He also said DeSantis is very successful, partially because of his MAGA agenda This may suggest a Trump-DeSantis pact isn‚Äôt completely out of the question for the 2024 presidential campaign.EXCLUSIVE: On Thursday's "Wake Up America," @RobFinnertyUSA asked fmr. President Donald Trump if his family supported a possible 2024 presidential campaign. pic.twitter.com/SKPGsYesKL‚Äî Newsmax (@newsmax) June 30, 2022
image_caption: Gov. Ron DeSantis, left, shakes hand with President Trump, right, at the Florida Fairgrounds. (AP Photo)

story_headline: Report: Rise in US disability rates coincides with vaccine rollout
story_copy: Report: Rise in US disability rates coincides with vaccine rolloutFILE ‚Äì A Northwell Health registered nurse fills a syringe with a COVID-19 vaccine at a pop up vaccination site the Albanian Islamic Cultural Center, April 8, 2021, in the Staten Island borough of New York. The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday, June 30, 2022 recommended that COVID-19 booster shots be modified to better match more recent variants of the coronavirus. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer, file)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 10:51 AM PT ‚Äì Thursday, June 30, 2022New data shows a spike in disability rates among US adults coincided with the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines, which is raising more questions about adverse effects. According to the data by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, the number of Americans with disabilities suddenly increased last year from 30 million to 32.7 million people.The St. Louis Fed data also shows the rate of disability remained stable between 2016 and 2020. The alarming rise in disabilities began in early 2021 just as Americans were mandated to take experimental vaccines for COVID-19. The report also shows more than 14,000 Americans reported being permanently disabled after receiving COVID shots.In the meantime, some medical professionals are questioning the vaccine‚Äôs exact side effects. One America‚Äôs Natasha Sweatte takes a closer look.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì A Northwell Health registered nurse fills a syringe with a COVID-19 vaccine at a pop up vaccination site the Albanian Islamic Cultural Center, April 8, 2021, in the Staten Island borough of New York. The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday, June 30, 2022 recommended that COVID-19 booster shots be modified to better match more recent variants of the coronavirus. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer, file)
more_news: ¬†Maj. Gen. Mick McGuire On Biden‚Äôs Disastrous Open Border PolicesTOPICS:COVIDCOVID-19COVID-19 vaccinesdisability ratesnewsOANOANNpoliticsSt LouisVaccines SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: Federal Reserve Chairman Powell admits US faces higher recession risk
story_copy: Federal Reserve Chairman Powell admits US faces higher recession riskFederal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell testifies before the House Financial Services Committee on Thursday, June 23, 2022 in Washington. (AP Photo/Kevin Wolf)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:15 AM PT ‚Äì Thursday, June 30, 2022Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell sent an alarming message about the state of the US economy on President Joe Biden‚Äôs watch. He admitted there‚Äôs no guarantee for so-called ‚Äúsoft landing‚Äù and a recession is possible.While speaking at a European Central Bank Forum in Portugal on Wednesday, Powell said he couldn‚Äôt guarantee that the Federal Reserve can bring inflation back down while also retaining a strong labor market. This means interest rates will continue to go up, which may cause an increase in unemployment.The Fed chair also added, he‚Äôs committed to utilizing every tool at his disposal to ensure economic stability, although he admitted there‚Äôs a risk for the Fed going too far and triggering a recession. His remarks came after the US Central Bank raised interest rates in an attempt to curb inflation.‚ÄúWe think that there are pathways for us to achieve the path back to 2 percent inflation while still retaining a strong labor market,‚Äù Powell stated. ‚ÄúWe believe we can do that. That is our aim. There‚Äôs no guarantee that we can do that.‚ÄùHis comments come as the Consumer Confidence Index dropped by 4.5 points this week. US consumers are expecting economic growth to ‚Äúsignificantly weaken‚Äù in the second half of this year. This drop has been attributed to a number of reasons such as rising costs for basic necessities, supply chain problems and concerns about the Russia-Ukraine conflict.Today, Chair Powell confirmed: @federalreserve's interest rate hikes won't bring down gas and food prices for families.But they could throw millions of out of their jobs, trigger a recession, and drive our economy off a cliff. pic.twitter.com/sD3fzn4KrZ‚Äî Elizabeth Warren (@SenWarren) June 22, 2022‚ÄúWe‚Äôre strongly committed to using our tools to get inflation to come down,‚Äù said Powell. ‚ÄúThe way to do that is to slow down growth, ideally keeping it positive. Is there a risk that would go too far? Certainly, there‚Äôs a risk.‚ÄùEconomists are saying the probability of the US experiencing a broad economic crisis is rising and could possibly occur in 2023 or even sooner. In the meantime, Biden still insists a recession is not inevitable, despite worsening projections by economists.Biden burying his head in the sand and denying that a recession is coming will not solve the problem. Returning to Trump‚Äôs policies will!‚Äî Rep. Lauren Boebert (@RepBoebert) June 21, 2022
image_caption: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell testifies before the House Financial Services Committee on Thursday, June 23, 2022 in Washington. (AP Photo/Kevin Wolf)

story_headline: Saudi Security Forces show strength ahead of Hajj, Biden visit
story_copy: Saudi Security Forces show strength ahead of Hajj, Biden visitMembers of the Saudi special forces perform a military parade in preparation for the annual Hajj pilgrimage, in the Muslim holy city of Mecca, Saudi Arabia, Sunday, July 3, 2022. (AP Photo/Amr Nabil)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:05 PM PT ‚Äì Sunday, July 3, 2022Saudi Arabia held a rare demonstration of its security forces and military preparedness ahead of Joe Biden‚Äôs visit. On Sunday, Saudi Security Forces held a parade in the city of Mecca as part of preparations for a major religious holiday.Authorities said millions of Muslim‚Äôs visited Mecca for Hajj celebrations, but only vaccinated or immunized worshippers were allowed to attend public events. Officials said the nation is prepared to address any potential security challenges.‚ÄúBy having these security forces and all military forces participating here today, we affirm our readiness to serve the guests of God,‚Äù said the Ministry of Interior spokesman Talal Al-Shalhoub. ‚ÄúWe are ready to implement the orders to preserve security and safety of the pilgrims in the state. This parade reflects the efforts of the king‚Äôs government towards the importance of holding the pilgrimage rituals safely and in peace.‚ÄùAt the Grand Hajj Symposium 2022 representing Pakistan in the Holy land of Makkah Mukarrama. pic.twitter.com/QLt4w3Htp0‚Äî Shoaib Akhtar (@shoaib100mph) July 3, 2022Crowd of pilgrims in the Mataaf increases, few days left for #hajj pic.twitter.com/3sSr9TSg3L‚Äî The Holy Mosque's (@theholymosques) June 27, 2022¬†President Joe Biden said Thursday he will not directly ask Saudi Arabia‚Äôs leaders to increase oil production when he visits the kingdom. He insisted that his trip to the Middle East is not focused on one-on-one engagement with King Salman or Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.‚ÄúThat is not the purpose of this trip, I‚Äôm not going to ask them,‚Äù Biden stated. ‚ÄúAll the Gulf states are meeting. I‚Äôve indicated to them that I thought they should be increasing oil production generically, not to Saudi Arabia in particular. I hope we see them in their own interests concluding that makes sense to do.‚ÄùBiden was counting on Arab nations to produce more oil but a few hours ago French President Macron was overheard telling Biden that the United Arab Emirates is at max capacity & the Saudis can‚Äôt produce much more. It appears to be a direct appeal to Biden to produce more oil. pic.twitter.com/vRWJVpn3El‚Äî Michael Shellenberger (@ShellenbergerMD) June 27, 2022Joe Biden will visit Saudi Arabia to discuss mutual ties as part of his upcoming tour of the Middle East. The tour will take place between July 13 and July 16.
image_caption: Members of the Saudi special forces perform a military parade in preparation for the annual Hajj pilgrimage, in the Muslim holy city of Mecca, Saudi Arabia, Sunday, July 3, 2022. (AP Photo/Amr Nabil)

story_headline: Experts warn Biden‚Äôs response to Monkeypox is ‚Äòslow‚Äô
story_copy: Experts warn Biden‚Äôs response to Monkeypox is ‚Äòslow‚ÄôA child affected by monkeypox, sits on his father‚Äôs legs while receiving treatment at the centre of the International medical NGO Doctors Without Borders (Medecins sans frontieres ‚Äì MSF), in Zomea Kaka, in the Lobaya region, in the Central African Republic on October 18, 2018. (Photo by CHARLES BOUESSEL /AFP via Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:13 PM PT ‚Äì Sunday, July 3, 2022Health care experts warned that the Monkeypox outbreak in America may get out of control. According to the National Coalition of STD Director‚Äôs, the Biden administration‚Äôs response to Monkeypox has been bureaucratic and slow."While the Emergency Committee didn't advise that the #monkeypox outbreak represents a Public Health Emergency of International Concern, they acknowledged the emergency nature of the event requiring intense response efforts"-@DrTedroshttps://t.co/cEwlELgC2v‚Äî World Health Organization (WHO) (@WHO) June 29, 2022The group argued that the lack of available vaccines, testing, and therapeutics are what may have allowed the infection to spread during the past month. This comes as the number of Monkeypox cases exceeded 350 as of last week. The WHO has also warned that sustainable transmission of Monkeypox posed a risk to susceptible demographics.‚ÄúThe virus has now been identified in more than 50 new countries and that trend is likely to continue,‚Äù said Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, Director-General of the World Health Organization. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm concerned about sustained transmission because it would suggest that the virus is establishing itself and it could move into high-risk groups including children, the immunocompromised and pregnant women. We‚Äôre starting to see this with several children already infected.‚ÄùMeanwhile, European countries have reported more than 4,000 cases of Monkeypox so far. Regional Director for WHO Europe Dr. Hans Kluge claimed that Europe accounts for nearly 90 percent of all confirmed and reported cases worldwide since mid-May.BREAKING‚Äî#Monkeypox has TRIPLED in just 2 weeks in Europe‚ÄîThe head of @WHO_Europe warns Europe cannot be complacent. He notes that 10% of all cases so far have been hospitalized for treatment or isolation. üìå@WHO need to declare PHEIC emergency. https://t.co/N0wIW6i8R1 pic.twitter.com/5w7jNpuz1v‚Äî Eric Feigl-Ding (@DrEricDing) July 1, 2022The Biden administration is planning to roll out a vaccination campaign in the US and it‚Äôs currently buying hundreds of thousands of vaccine doses.

story_headline: 3-year-old dies after falling from balcony in NYC
story_copy: 3-year-old dies after falling from balcony in NYCMINNEAPOLIS, MN ‚Äì JUNE 16: A Minneapolis Police officer rolls up caution tape at a crime scene on June 16, 2020 in Minneapolis, Minnesota. (Photo by Brandon Bell/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 5:20 PM PT ‚Äì Sunday, July 3, 2022A toddler died after falling off the balcony of a high rise in Harlem, New York City. On Saturday, police found a three-year-old boy sprawled across the fifth floor scaffolding of the Taino Towers residential complex after he fell off the 29th floor. Neighbors said they heard adult‚Äôs from the boy‚Äôs unit arguing on the terrace shortly before they heard a ‚Äúbig thump.‚ÄùNidia Cordero, a close neighbor of the family who would often lend money to the boy‚Äôs mother for milk and diapers said the family has a history of domestic violence.‚ÄúThere was a fight every single day, said Cordero. ‚ÄúThere was not one day that there was not a fight.‚ÄùWitnesses recalled hearing the child‚Äôs mother scream from the street below as the father ran down the stairs in tears. He reportedly attempted to climb onto the scaffolding to get his child, but was ultimately unsuccessful.‚ÄúYou got to watch your children,‚Äù voiced a neighbor. ‚ÄúYou take your eyes off a kid one time and your done. Anything can happen.‚ÄùA toddler fell from a balcony on the 29th floor & landed on the 3rd floor scaffolding of the Taino Towers in East Harlem this morning. The little boy was taken to Harlem Hospital & was pronounced dead. NYPD questioning parents to find out what went wrong. @NBCNewYork pic.twitter.com/lb63d5dJCs‚Äî Melissa Colorado (@melissacolorado) July 2, 2022The toddler was immediately rushed to Harlem Hospital where he was pronounced dead. Meanwhile, how the boy fell exactly remains under investigation. Officials do not know whether the boy fell from a window or balcony, but under New York City law owners of apartment buildings are required to install window guards if a tenant is under the age of 10.In the meantime, authorities said a preliminary investigation showed the child‚Äôs death was accidental.
image_caption: MINNEAPOLIS, MN ‚Äì JUNE 16: A Minneapolis Police officer rolls up caution tape at a crime scene on June 16, 2020 in Minneapolis, Minnesota. (Photo by Brandon Bell/Getty Images)

story_headline: Akron Police release footage of deadly shooting
story_copy: Akron Police release footage of deadly shootingCrime scene police tape in front of blue and red police lights at night. Image by Gerd AltmannOAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:24 PM PT ‚Äì Sunday, July 3, 2022Authorities braced themselves for protests in Akron, Ohio after the deadline for police to release the body camera footage of a fatal shooting closed in. On Sunday, Akron Police released the footage and provided details of the shooting during a joint press conference with the mayor.Officials said two officers attempted to pull over 25-year-old Jayland Walker Monday night and a gun was fired along the drivers side of the vehicle. Walker fled from the car wearing a ski mask and police said the deployment of tasers were unsuccessful. Eight officers followed on foot and reportedly fired more than 60 rounds.‚ö†Ô∏èWarning: GRAPHICAkron Police just released the body camera footage of the killing of Jayland Walker.Jayland was unarmed and running away when police opened fire, firing 90 shots, hitting him 60.The Department of Justice needs to step in to investigate immediately. pic.twitter.com/owMmoSwFCi‚Äî Nina Turner (@ninaturner) July 3, 2022‚ÄúThe video is heartbreaking, it‚Äôs hard to take in,‚Äù said Akron Mayor Daniel Horrigan. ‚ÄúIndependence Day is meant to be a celebration and a time of gathering with friends and family. Unfortunately, I feel strongly that this is not the time for a city-led celebration.‚ÄùThe incident was the third fatal shooting by a police officer in Akron in the past six months. On Saturday, a crowd of more than 100 people gathered outside the city courthouse and chanted ‚ÄúNo justice, no peace, prosecute the police.‚Äù Demonstrators have gathered everyday since and police have urged for peaceful protests as the investigation continues.‚ÄúWe are done dying like this,‚Äù said attorney Paige White. ‚ÄúIn this manner, with this fate. No one should ever suffer the fate that Jayland Walker did.‚ÄùHis name is Jayland Walker. ‚Å£‚Å£8 Akron Ohio cops fired 90 bullets at him, hitting him 60 times throughout hie entire body. ‚Å£The cops pulled him over for a TRAFFIC VIOLATION. He was 25.He was a @doordash driver. HE WAS UNARMED.HE WAS MURDERED.#JaylandWalker pic.twitter.com/CLqQtgx1ZQ‚Äî Bishop Talbert Swan (@TalbertSwan) June 30, 2022In the meantime, all officers have been placed on paid administrative leave. This is routine when involved in a deadly situation. They have all been cooperative throughout the investigation.

story_headline: Texas murder suspect, Kaitlin Armstrong, booked in Harris County Jail
story_copy: Texas murder suspect, Kaitlin Armstrong, booked in Harris County JailHandcuffs sit on a table in this file photo. (Credit: Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 3:20 PM PT ‚Äì Sunday, July 3, 2022A Texas woman accused of killing a professional cyclist was extradited to Houston, Texas after being captured in Costa Rica. On Saturday, 34-year-old Kaitlin Armstrong was escorted by US Marshals at the George Bush International Airport and was later booked in the Harris County Jail.The Austin woman accused of killing world class cyclist Anna Moriah Wilson May 11 has been captured in Costa Rica.https://t.co/fz9FiUyWjQ pic.twitter.com/jkRzqqgv90‚Äî U.S. Marshals (@USMarshalsHQ) June 30, 2022Exclusive footage from KTRK showed Armstrong in handcuffs with her new look after she cut and dyed her hair. Officials believe she may have also gotten cosmetic surgery. The suspect is accused of killing 25-year-old Moriah Wilson after Wilson spent the day with Armstrong‚Äôs boyfriend. According to an affidavit, Wilson had previously dated Armstrong‚Äôs boyfriend, cyclist Colin Strickland. He has cooperated with investigators and is not a suspect.ARREST PHOTO üíØ‚öñÔ∏è This was taken at Kaitlin Armstrong‚Äôs arrest in Costa Rica! Armstrong is accused of murdering world class cyclist Anna Wilson.She‚Äôll be sent back to Austin, TX for prosecution! @USMarshalsHQ @CourtTV @CourtTVUK pic.twitter.com/6zerKfgvNt‚Äî Julie Grant (@JulieCourtTV) July 1, 2022Costa Rican authorities apprehended Armstrong on a remote beach area after 43 days on the run. She will be transferred to Austin where she faces murder charges.‚ÄúThe Marshals Service elevated the Kaitlin Armstrong investigation to major case status early in this investigation,‚Äù said U.S. Marshal for the Western District of Texas Susan Pamerleau. ‚ÄúThis likely played a key role in her capture.‚ÄùAuthorities said Armstrong sold her vehicle May 13, then flew from Austin to Houston shortly after being questioned that day by authorities about Wilson‚Äôs death. She then flew to New York before using a fraudulent passport to fly from Newark, New Jersey, to San Jose, Costa Rica on May 18.Her bond is set for $3.5 million.

story_headline: Historic rulings define latest Supreme Court term
story_copy: Historic rulings define latest Supreme Court termFILE ‚Äì This Oct. 4, 2018, file photo shows the U.S. Supreme Court at sunset in Washington.¬† (AP Photo/Manuel Balce Ceneta, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 10:54 AM PT ‚Äì Friday, July 1, 2022The Supreme Court issued its final ruling of the term, wrapping up a historic session packed with several prominent rulings. In a five to four decision Thursday, the nation‚Äôs highest court ruled the Biden administration can terminate the Trump-era Remain in Mexico policy. The high court found the administration‚Äôs push to end the policy did not violate federal immigration law.Justices John Roberts and Brett Kavanaugh sided with the court‚Äôs liberal justices in the ruling. The policy, first enacted in 2019, required asylum seekers to stay in Mexico while their claims were processed in court. Thursday‚Äôs decision now paves the way for Biden to go through with ending the policy. Texas Governor Greg Abbott (R) has called on the Biden administration to reinstate Trump-era policies, while asserting they have proved to be effective.‚ÄúBuilding a border wall, keeping in place both Title 42 and the Remain in Mexico policy and enforcing those,‚Äù Abbott stated. ‚ÄúSo, those policies remain in effect right now. However, it is my understanding that the way we see it, Biden is not enforcing those. Ending catch and release. Those are the four things that are very simple to do.‚ÄùEarlier, the Supreme Court sided with Joseph Kennedy, a former high school football coach in Washington State, who was let go for publicly praying on the field after games. In the court‚Äôs opinion, Justice Neil Gorsuch explained that both the free exercise and free speech clauses of the First Amendment protect expressions like Mr. Kennedy‚Äôs.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not for the Christians or the Jews, or the atheists or whoever,‚Äù said Kennedy. ‚ÄúIt is for all Americans and that‚Äôs why I thought this was such a huge win. It‚Äôs more a freedom of speech thing for me personally because it was just a moment between me and God. It had nothing to do with anybody else.‚ÄùAdditionally, the Supreme Court issued a ruling limiting the federal government‚Äôs authority to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from power plants. In a six-to-three decision, the court ruled the EPA cannot pass sweeping carbon dioxide emissions regulations without congressional approval. This is a victory for West Virginia and a number of other GOP-led states that challenged the EPA while arguing the Clean Air Act did not give the agency power to impose such broad regulations.The ruling could have far reaching ramifications as it may curb the Biden administrations capability to promote green energy through regulations on carbon dioxide emissions. West Virginia Attorney General Patrick Morrisey responded to the Supreme Courts decision and thanked all the states that were part of the process.Alos, the Supreme Court welcomed Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson Thursday as she was sworn in as the first black woman to serve on the nations highest court. Supreme Court Justice Stephen Breyer officially stepped down from the bench after a 28-year career. Jackson is slated to participate in arguments for the first time during the court‚Äôs next term beginning in October.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì This Oct. 4, 2018, file photo shows the U.S. Supreme Court at sunset in Washington.¬† (AP Photo/Manuel Balce Ceneta, File)

To Bar Concealed Carry In Various Locations, Increase RequirementsTOPICS:Biden AdministrationborderBorder Crisisborder wallClean Air ActclimateConstitutionEmissionsEPAFirst Amendment pgovernmentgreen energyGreg AbbottimmigrationJoseph Kennedyketanji brown jacksonNeil GorsuchnewsOANOANNpoliticsRemain in MexicoStephen BreyerSupreme Court SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: Supreme Court EPA decision met with mixed reactions
story_copy: Supreme Court EPA decision met with mixed reactionsFILE ‚Äì Steam billows from a coal-fired power plant Nov. 18, 2021, in Craig, Colo. The Supreme Court on Thursday, June 30, 2022, voted 6-3, with conservatives in the majority, that the Clean Air Act does not give the Environmental Protection Agency broad authority to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from power plants. (AP Photo/Rick Bowmer, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:20 AM PT ‚Äì Friday, July 1, 2022The Supreme Court ruled that the Clean Air Act does not give the EPA broad or expansive powers to regulate carbon emissions, in turn, leaving it up to states. In a six to three vote on Thursday, the high court decided the executive agency could not impose regulations on states that restrict carbon emissions to encourage a transfer to renewable energy.The decision was met with praise from Republicans who argued the EPA could not implement such regulations nationally, while Democrats viewed it as a step backwards in fighting so-called climate change. West Virginia Attorney General Patrick Morrisey, who spearheaded the legal challenge, called the decision a huge victory because it reaffirms the concept of separation of powers.‚ÄúWe want to make sure that the Biden agenda is limited by basis of what Congress authorized these agencies,‚Äù Morrisey. ‚ÄúWhat a concept that is and this should not be considered to be anything other than consistent with the Constitution, the rule of law, and our separation of powers.‚ÄùMeanwhile across the aisle, several Democrat governors vowed to double down on their efforts to fight so-called climate change. Washington Governor Jay Inslee (D) expressed disappointment in the decision and said state and local governments will have to pick up where the executive branch left off.‚ÄúWe have to accelerate our efforts to reduce carbon pollution in the state of Washington in the upcoming years and that‚Äôs necessary because the federal government now is going to be, frankly, much less effective in restraining pollution, which means more of that burden is going to be on our shoulders,‚Äù said Inslee. ‚ÄúAnd we are willing to accept that because Washington State is not going to allow climate change to swallow our state.‚ÄùInslee did not clarify what he plans to do in light of the ruling. However, California Governor¬† (D) took a more direct approach by announcing on Twitter that he will be signing a $54 billion climate fighting plan.‚ÄúThe idea that the US Supreme Court moved to take away one of the most significant and historically powerful tools to address the ravages of climate change is incomprehensible,‚Äù asserted Newsom. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got to wake up to what‚Äôs going on, Supreme Court. And we‚Äôve got to double down, quadruple down here in California and in blue states all across America.‚ÄùThis Supreme Court is hell bent on turning back the clock and ignoring reality. Now, they have kneecapped the federal government‚Äôs ability to tackle climate change.Today, I‚Äôm signing a $54 BILLION¬†climate-fighting plan. CA will keep leading the way. pic.twitter.com/QhJfA2DofE‚Äî Gavin Newsom (@GavinNewsom) June 30, 2022In the meantime, Democrat lawmakers are making a push to pass legislation codifying the EPA‚Äôs authority.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Steam billows from a coal-fired power plant Nov. 18, 2021, in Craig, Colo. The Supreme Court on Thursday, June 30, 2022, voted 6-3, with conservatives in the majority, that the Clean Air Act does not give the Environmental Protection Agency broad authority to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from power plants. (AP Photo/Rick Bowmer, File)
